title-group.article-title: Mn3O4 nano-octahedrons embedded in nitrogen-doped graphene oxide as potent anode material for lithium-ion batteries

institution-wrap.institution: Department of Chemistry and DST-Solar Energy Harnessing Centre
Rajiv Gandhi University of Knowledge Technologies

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Mn3O4 nano-octahedrons embedded in N-doped graphene oxide (MNGO) nanosheets were synthesized using a simple, energy-efficient, and rapid microwave-digested hydrothermal route in a single step. The structural and morphological aspects of synthesized materials were evaluated by XRD, IR, Raman, FE-SEM, and HR-TEM techniques. Then, the composite MNGO was tested for its Li-ion storage properties and compared with reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and Mn3O4 materials. The MNGO composite exhibited superior reversible specific capacity, excellent cyclic stability, and outstanding structural integrity throughout the electrochemical studies. The MNGO composite showed a reversible capacity of 898 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1 and Coulombic efficiency of 97.8%. Even at a higher current density of 500 mA g−1, it exhibits a higher specific capacity of 532 mA h g−1 (~1.5 times higher than commercial graphite anode). These results demonstrate that Mn3O4 nano-octahedrons embedded on N-doped GO are a highly durable and potent anode material for LIBs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lithium-ion–based rechargeable batteries are the most successful and clean energy storage devices powering many portable electronic devices and transforming the transportation sector of modern society with zero carbon emission [1]. The superiority of LIBs is credited to their high energy density (100–265 Wh/kg), high open-circuit voltage (~ 3.6 V), low self-discharge (~ 5% per month), long lifespan, lightweight, and eco-friendliness [2, 3]. Battery (redox) chemistry made possible the rapid digitalization of modern society in all sectors during the COVID-19 pandemic period. The current commercial batteries using graphite as anode material which has a moderate capacity of 372 mA h g−1 resulting from the composition LiC6 cannot fulfill the current high energy demands [3–5]. Therefore, studying new strategies and materials is desirable to achieve high energy density, good cyclic stability, and safer Li-ion technology [6].

Transition metal oxides (TMOs) have been regarded as a good choice of materials with high theoretical capacities (500–1000 mA h g−1) ascribed to the formation of MLi6 per unit formula, thus giving high-energy density materials [7]. Furthermore, Nano-sized TMOs are an attractive alternative to graphite anode since they facilitate high surface area, shorter lithium diffusion path length, and minimal strains during Li insertion/extraction [8]. Among TMOs, Hausmannite Mn3O4, which is a normal spinel in which the Mn2+ ions occupy tetrahedral voids and Mn3+ ions occupy octahedral voids, is one of the best choices of materials with diverse applications in the areas of LIBs [9, 10], supercapacitors, [11, 12], catalysis [13, 14], etc., by virtue of their high theoretical capacity (937 mA h g−1), natural abundance, relatively low cost, and environmental friendliness [15]. However, its applications are remarkably bounded by its poor electrical conductivity (10−7–10−8 S cm−1), which kinetically limits its rate capability, and significant volume variations can manifest its capacity loss during Li insertion/extraction [16]. These shortcomings may be addressed by hybridizing manganese oxides with a conductive carbon source such as carbon nanotubes, graphene, and graphene oxide as a composite. Many synthetic procedures are reported to prepare Mn3O4/GO hybrids such as hydrothermal [17, 18], ultrasound [19], solvothermal [20], precipitation [21], and microwave-assisted hydrothermal [22]. The hydrothermal approach is the most widely used method to make metal oxide composites, which involves a chemical reaction in water in a sealed pressure vessel at high temperatures and pressure for a long time. In contrast to the above conventional methods, a microwave-assisted hydrothermal method is an attractive option due to its short time, simple, facile composition, and growth control characteristics [22–24].

Graphene, a hexagonal sheet of sp2 carbon atoms with a free electron at each sp2 carbon, is a conductive wonder in energy research that provides good electronic, structural, and mechanical support to the TMOs [14, 23]. The electronic properties of the graphene can be further tuned by doping/co-doping with heteroatoms such as nitrogen, sulfur, and phosphorous to improve its energy storage capability [25–27]. In recent years, N-doped graphene oxide has been explored as better anode material for Li-ion storage than simple graphene and graphene oxide (GO). The doped nitrogen atoms could offer more active sites, increasing the effective interaction between graphene and lithium ions [14, 28]. This profoundly improves the kinetic diffusion and transfer of Li-ions with better storage properties. Several research groups have prepared different manganese oxide-graphene composites such as Mn3O4/graphene [17, 29], Mn3O4/rGO [11, 22, 30], Mn3O4/carbon nanotubes [31, 32], and Mn3O4/N-doped graphene [3, 18, 33] through hydrothermal synthesis and tested as anode for LIBs. The synergy of graphene and Mn3O4 composites has improved the performance of Li-ion storage. Nevertheless, those nanostructured materials suffer from poor structural stability, less cyclic stability, and low Coulombic efficiency.

We prepared a N-doped graphene oxide/Mn3O4 composite (MNGO) using a microwave-digested hydrothermal route in a facile single-step process. The microwave-assisted hydrothermal method we employed to synthesize the material is more energy-efficient and time-saving (30 min). The composite Mn3O4-NGO was synthesized via in situ generation and incorporates a large amount of N-content in the graphene sheets, which may efficiently enhance the Li+ ion diffusion. The MNGO composite exhibited superior reversible specific capacity, excellent cyclic stability, and outstanding structural integrity throughout the electrochemical studies compared to similar materials prepared via other synthetic routes. The MNGO composite showed a reversible capacity of 898 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at a current density of 100 mA g−1 and Coulombic efficiency of 97.8%. Even at a higher current density of 500 mA g−1, it exhibits a higher specific capacity of 532 mA h g−1 (~ 1.5 times higher than commercial graphite anode).

sec.title: Synthesis of Mn3O4-NGO composite
sec.p:
The chemicals used in the experiment are of analytical grade and used without further purification. We employed a modified Hummer’s method to synthesize the graphene oxide (GO) from graphite powder [34]. MNGO composites are synthesized in a facile one-step microwave-assisted hydrothermal route in a microwave digester. In a typical synthesis, 8 mg of GO in 13 mL of DMF solvent (0.8 M) was sonicated for 20 min and added to 60 mL of dextrose (4.72 g, 0.2 M) solution. The above mixture was kept in an ice bath, and ~ 1 mL of NH3 (25%) solution (in order to maintain a pH of ~ 9 to 10) and 0.8 mL of hydrazine hydrate solution were injected by micropipette with constant stirring for 10 min. Finally, the solution was made up to 100 mL, and KMnO4 (1.037 g in 30 mL) was added to the reaction mixture and immediately transferred into Teflon microwave autoclaves (8 × 15 mL) and irradiated with microwaves for 30 min under calcite digestion conditions. The entire contents were allowed to reach ambient temperature naturally. The solid product was collected and centrifuged with deionized water and ethanol several times, and the solid settled after the centrifugation process and was dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h. It was further calcined in a tubular furnace from room temperature to 450 °C at a heating rate of 2.5 °C min−1 and kept for 4 h in a nitrogen gas atmosphere. Similarly, pristine Mn3O4 was prepared without graphene oxide. The chemical process followed for the preparation of composite material is presented in Scheme 1.Scheme 1
Schematic illustration of the Mn3O4-NGO composite preparation using a microwave digester

sec.title: Material characterization
sec.p: The product’s powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern was determined by BRUKER AXS D8 advanced diffractometer at room temperature with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The morphology and microstructure of the products after calcination were probed using ZEISS field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) and FP 5022/22-Tecnai G2 20 S-TWIN high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). Raman spectrum was recorded using a Raman system-Witec alpha 300R, which used excitation wavelength 532 nm, and Nd-YAG laser as the excitation source. X-ray photoelectron microscopy (XPS) analysis was done using a Thermofisher scientific (NEXSA base model) with a micro-focused X-ray (400 μm, 72 W, 12,000 V) monochromatic Al-Kα source (hν = 1486.6 eV). Survey and multi-region spectra were recorded at Mn 2p, N1s, C1s, and O1s photoelectron peaks. The XPS data were analyzed with the Origin pro (2018) version using Shirley type background and Gaussian peak fitting function.

sec.title: Electrochemical measurements
sec.p: The working electrode was fabricated by mixing 75 wt% active material, 15 wt% acetylene black, and 10 wt% polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF, as a binder). The contents were ball-milled using a sufficient quantity of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) as a solvent to make homogenous electrode slurry. Subsequently, the slurry was coated onto the copper foil (current collector) using a doctor blade and dried at 90 °C overnight in a vacuum oven. CR2025 coin-type half-cells were made into disks inside an argon-filled glove box (under < 1 ppm concentrations of O2 and H2O). The cell performance of the active materials was tested using CR2025-type coin half-cells with metallic lithium foil as a counter electrode and polypropylene (Celgard 2500) as a separator. An electrolytic solution containing 1 M LiPF6 dissolved in ethylene carbonate and diethyl carbonate (1:1 v/v) was used as a solvent. The electrochemical properties of fabricated Mn3O4-NGO composite and other materials (rGO and pristine Mn3O4) were assessed using the techniques cyclic voltammetry (0.01–3.0 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mV/s) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (0.1 Hz to 1 MHz) on a versa-STAT electrochemical work station. The energy storage performance was evaluated by cycling galvanostatic charge/discharge studies with a LAND battery testing instrument at different current densities (voltage range of 0.01–3.0 V) under ambient temperature conditions. For the normalized current density of different active materials compared, approximately 2 mg/cm2 of samples was coated. The electrochemical analysis of active materials was carried out at 100 mA/g and 500 mA/g.

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p:
The phase structure of the synthesized materials was analyzed by X-ray diffraction technique and presented in Fig. 1a. Figure 1 a shows the diffraction pattern of reduced graphene oxide (rGO), pristine Mn3O4, and Mn3O4-NGO composite. A broad peak centered at 2θ = 28° corresponds to reduced GO’s (002) plane, which has an amorphous carbon skeleton with disordered stacking of graphene layers [16, 35, 36]. The diffraction patterns of synthesized Mn3O4 and Mn3O4-NGO are well indexed to Hausmannite Mn3O4 with tetragonal crystal system (ICSD no. 98-008-9972) and I41/amd space group [9]. No other characteristic impurity peaks are observed in the crystalline phase of Mn3O4-NGO, which indicates the formation of the pure phase of Mn3O4 nanoparticles. Furthermore, no graphitic peaks are noted in the MNGO composite, indicating that the rGO sheets are sufficiently separated from Mn3O4 particles [36]. The intensity of diffraction peaks reflects the size of the particles in the crystal. The larger the particle size, the higher the intensity of the peaks and vice versa. In the case of MNGO, the intensity of the peaks is relatively low, which can be ascribed to the smaller crystallite size of Mn3O4 particles distributed on N-doped graphene sheets. This can be credited to the presence of a graphitic material that prevents the agglomeration of particles and results in small and well-separated metal oxide particles in the composite [33]. Debye-Scherrer’s formula uses full width at half-maximum (FWHM) peaks to evaluate the average crystallite size of Mn3O4 particles embedded on N-doped GO and found to be ~ 20 nm.Fig. 1
a Powder XRD pattern and b IR spectra of rGO, Mn3O4 and Mn3O4-NGO

sec.title: FT-IR analysis
sec.p: The bond properties of synthesized samples were evaluated using Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy. The peaks in the spectrum arise due to the characteristic vibrational frequency of a bond. The presence of peaks at a particular wavenumber suggests the existence of that bond in the given sample, which in turn confirms its formation. The FT-IR spectra of samples rGO, Mn3O4, and MNGO are shown in Fig. 1b. The IR spectrum of rGO showing a broad peak centered at 3212 cm−1 represents an O–H stretching vibration [21]. The peaks at 1544 and 1094 cm−1 illustrate the presence of C=C and C–OH stretching vibrations, respectively. The FT-IR spectrum of Mn3O4 and Mn3O4-NGO composites has almost diminished typical peaks of rGO and the new peaks at 604 and 482 cm−1. These peaks may be attributed to Mn–O stretching vibrations in their tetrahedral and octahedral voids, respectively [17, 37]. These peaks support the formation of the Mn3O4-NGO composite.

sec.title: Raman spectra analysis
sec.p:
Raman spectroscopy is performed to evaluate synthesized samples’ crystallinity, defects, and disorder of microstructures. The Raman spectra arise from the elastic bond vibrations in the crystalline and amorphous phases. It provides complementary structural information to XRD and FT-IR techniques. The typical Raman curves of rGO, Mn3O4, and MNGO in Fig. 2 confirm the formation of nanocomposites. In the Raman spectra of rGO, an intense peak is observed at 1363 cm−1, called the D-band. It represents the lattice defects and disorder carbon in graphite layers, another intense peak at 1602 cm−1, known as G-band. It represents in-plane bond stretching vibrations of sp2 C-atoms in the graphite sheet with an intensity ratio of ID/IG, 1.03. For MNGO, the D and G bands are observed at 1361 and 1600 cm−1 having an ID/IG ratio of 1.13 [23, 38]. The introduction of nitrogen into the lattice sites of graphene oxide creates more structural defects that shift the D and G bands, increasing the intensity ratio of the D band to the G band. The increased intensity ratio for doped GO in MNGO (1.13) than rGO (1.03) evidences the lattice defects in the graphene sheets and in close agreement to the N-doped graphene (1.15) reported earlier [39]. The intensity ratio of ID/IG reflects the degree of disorder of graphitic layers and signifies that composite MNGO is more disordered than rGO. The increased ID/IG ratio for MNGO demonstrates the intimate interaction of Mn3O4 nanoparticles over the surface of graphitic layers and can induce more defects and disorders [3]. Raman spectrum evidenced the presence of adequate disorders in the N-doped graphene lattice which is crucial for efficient Li-ion diffusion and storage characteristics [40]. Furthermore, a prominent peak observed at 637 and 650 cm−1 of Mn3O4 and MNGO, respectively, corresponds to the Mn–O vibrational mode that confirms the formation of the Mn3O4 phase. The peak shift observed in the Mn–O bond of Mn3O4 and MNGO further evidences the effective interaction between graphene layers and Mn3O4 nanoparticles [33]. This interface contact is essential for metal oxide/graphene-based composites, favoring efficient charge transfer behavior that could synergistically improve its Li-storage properties.Fig. 2
Raman spectra of rGO, Mn3O4, and Mn3O4-NGO composite

sec.title: SEM and TEM analysis
sec.p:
The field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) were employed to probe the morphology and microstructures of synthesized samples. The thin nanosheets of rGO with crumpled morphology are clearly shown in the SEM image (Fig. S1 (a-b)). The nanosheets show a uniform and smooth surface that may disappear in the metal oxide composite due to embedded Mn3O4 particles throughout the graphene oxide layers. The SEM images of Mn3O4 (Fig. 3a, b) show many spherical-like nanoparticles which are strongly aggregated together, resulting in a massive cluster-like morphology [36]. In contrast, no aggregation is observed in microstructures of the MNGO composite (Fig. 3c, d), and the entire surface metal oxide nanoparticles are completely embedded with flexible and thin sheets of conductive graphene [37]. The oxygen-containing functional groups of rGO assist the nucleation and anchoring of metal-oxide nanocrystals on the graphene sheets to achieve covalent interactions, which help to shape the uniform formation of Mn3O4. The synergistic effect between graphene sheets and metal oxide particles controlled the size (Mn3O4), restacking (NGO), and aggregation. The covalent interaction between oxygen-functionalities of graphene and Mn3O4 nanocrystals improves the conductivity of the composite. Moreover, this distinct nanoarchitecture affords abundant pores and channels for efficient ion transport, and intrinsic wrinkles on the N-doped GO surface offer more active sites for Li-ion insertion [16]. Transmission electron microscopy was used to reveal the distinct microstructures of the MNGO composite. The TEM images of rGO shown in Fig. S1 (c-d) reveal the presence of transparent nanosheets with monoatomic thickness. The basal planes of rGO are curled and disordered, which could facilitate Li-ion diffusion [40]. Figure 4 shows the typical HR-TEM images of Mn3O4 octahedrons (~ 20 nm) embedded in ultrathin nanosheets of N-doped graphene oxide. It is clearly seen that the Mn3O4 nano-octahedrons are randomly distributed in the N-doped graphene oxide (NGO) thin sheets. The springe spacing was calculated to be 0.248 nm, corresponding to the (121) crystal planes of the tetragonal Mn3O4 spinel. The histogram of the crystallite size of particles shown in the inset of Fig. 4a reveals that most of the metal oxide particles (~ 80%) have a diameter of ~ 20 nm, perfectly complemented with the XRD data. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of Mn3O4-NGO is presented in Fig. 4d, and its dispersed rings suggested the more amorphous nature of the sample. This may be ascribed to the occurrence of an enormous amount of graphene layers which are amorphous with a little amount of embedded crystalline metal oxide particles in a random fashion.Fig. 3
a, b SEM images of Mn3O4 and c, d Mn3O4-NGO at different magnificationsFig. 4
a–c TEM and HR-TEM images of Mn3O4-NGO composite at different magnifications; d SAED pattern of the corresponding sample

sec.title: XPS analysis
sec.p:
The chemical composition and bonding state of the Mn3O4-NGO composite was investigated using XPS spectra. Figure 5 a represents the XPS survey scan of elements in the composite material. The survey spectrum analysis evidences the presence of Mn, C, N, and O elements with the % composition of 4.82, 74.17, 14.23, and 6.78 respectively without any impurities. Figure 5 b depicts the spectrum of Mn2p. The two peaks located at 641.8 and 653.76 eV may be assigned to the Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 spin states, which are well documented in the literature [6, 41, 42]. The Mn 2p doublet with a spin energy separation of 11.9 eV is also characteristic of the Mn3O4 spinel. The XPS spectrum of C1s is presented in Fig. 5c. Three peaks at binding energies 284.9, 285.4, and 286.8 eV correspond to well-ordered graphitic (sp2) carbon, amorphous carbon (C–N), and C–O functionalities respectively [15]. The appearance of a peak at 285.4 confirms the insertion of the N-atom into the carbon (graphene) framework [3]. Furthermore, the intensity of the peak corresponding to C–N is comparable with the C–C/C=C peak evidencing the significant N-doping onto the carbon framework. Additionally, the intensity of C–O functionalities at 286.8 eV is diminished profoundly due to the reduction of oxygen-containing groups in the graphene oxide sheet. The deconvoluted N1s spectra are shown in Fig. 5d, and its signature peaks are characterized as follows. A peak at 399.4 eV depicts the pyridinic N, a peak at 400.9 eV is attributed to pyrrolic N, and another peak at 401.2 eV may be assigned to the pyridinic-N-oxide form of nitrogen in the GO matrix [14]. The high intensity of the pyridinic N peak suggests doping of a large amount of pyridinic form of nitrogen in the carbon lattice that offers excellent electron mobility and good electrochemical activity [43]. The doping of nitrogen is believed to inherit from hydrazine in the solution. The ratio of N-doping in composite often depends on the synthesis methods employed and the extended time and temperature applied. Due to the impulsiveness of the reaction during microwave radiation, it is expected to incorporate more nitrogen content than the conventional hydrothermal method. We observed that the percentage of nitrogen loading in our sample is 14.2% due to high pressure and elevated temperature during the microwave-digested route. The previous reports observed that through various synthetic routes, only 3–8.9% loading was reported [42]. Based on previous reports, the co-existence of electron deficiency and vacancies at the pyridine-like defects offers a feasible pathway for efficient Li-ion insertion/extraction and thus improves the electrochemical performance of N-doped graphene composites [44]. The deconvoluted spectrum of O1s with the three peaks located at 530.1 eV, 531.8, and 533.2 eV may be attributed to Mn–O–Mn, Mn–OH, and water form of oxygen respectively (Fig. S2).Fig. 5
Deconvoluted XPS spectra of a general survey of Mn3O4-NGO composite, b Mn2p, c C1s, and d N1s

sec.title: Electrochemical measurements
sec.p:
The manganese oxide composites are good candidates as anode materials for LIBs due to their impressive theoretical capacity, low cost, and environmental benignity. The electrochemical properties of Mn3O4-NGO were investigated along with rGO and pristine Mn3O4 for comparison as anode material for LIBs. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) is an effective method to establish the mechanistic aspects of charge/discharge in energy storage devices. Firstly, the redox properties of the Mn3O4 and MNGO were illustrated using cyclic voltammetry (CV) studies and presented in Fig. 6. Figure 6 a and b show the CV curves of the first three cycles of Mn3O4, and Mn3O4-NGO hybrid electrodes that are cycled between 3.0 and 0.01 V at 0.1 mV/s scan rate. The cyclic voltammetry of Mn3O4 and Mn3O4-NGO showed similar redox properties in their CV profile, suggesting a similar electrochemical (redox) behavior at the given voltage range. The CV responses agree with the previously reported Mn3O4 material/composite as the anode in LIBs [31, 45, 46]. The electrochemical behavior of samples may be explained as follows. In the first cathodic sweep of Mn3O4-NGO (Mn3O4), small peaks observed at 1.39 (0.83 V) and 1.10 V (1.29 V) are observed that disappeared in the subsequent cycles. These peaks may be attributed to the formation of inevitable and stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) complemented by the decomposition of electrolyte solvents. An intense spike at a lower potential of 0.12 V (0.13 V) represents the unique conversion-based reaction of Mn3O4 to Mn(0) with the subsequent formation of lithia (Li2O) matrix [35, 45]. In the consecutive cycles, the peak reduction potential is shifted more positively, 0.34 V (0.35 V). The more positive shift in potential arises due to structural deformations during lithium insertion in the conversion of reaction-based anode materials. This positive shift indicates reduced polarization and improved kinetics after the first lithiation. In the anodic sweep, two peaks observed at 1.31 (1.32 V) and 2.09 V (2.12 V) illustrate the reverse reaction of metallic Mn to MnO and then to Mn3O4 along with Li2O decomposition. This electrochemical conversion reaction may be represented as Mn3O4 + 8Li+ + 8e− ↔ 3Mn + 4Li2O [33, 35, 45]. The successive cycles are perfectly overlapping with each other indicating the excellent stability and good reversibility of the Mn3O4-NGO hybrid.Fig. 6
Cyclic voltammetry profiles (first three cycles) of a Mn3O4 and b Mn3O4-NGO

Galvanostatic charge/discharge studies further evaluate the Li storage properties of synthesized materials. Figure 7 c represents the charge/discharge profiles of Mn3O4-NGO composite (first six cycles) that are scanned within the voltage of 0.01 to 3.0 V (vs Li/Li+) at 100 mA g−1 current density. The opening discharge/charge capacities and Coulombic efficiency of Mn3O4-NGO are 1083/966 mA h g−1 and ~ 89%, respectively. The initial Coulombic efficiency loss may be ascribed to the irreversible processes (electrolyte decomposition and SEI formation) that will occur at the interface of the solid and its electrolyte, as reported in previous literature [31, 35, 45, 46]. In the first discharge (lithiation) process, a sloping plateau is observed within the voltage range of around 1.6–0.5 V attributed to the reaction of Li-ions with the graphene oxide layer and subsequent SEI formation. The flat voltage plateau at ~ 0.5 V corresponds to the reduction of Mn3O4 to Mn(0) metal coupled with Li2O matrix formation. The successive cycles are diverse from the first cycle, and there is a voltage plateau at ~ 0.6 V, which is distinctly higher than the first discharge cycle. It further reveals that the subsequent lithiation processes are the more effortless and often characteristic feature of single-phase conversion reactions [32]. In the first charging curve (i.e., delithiation process), a plateau at ~ 1.05 V implies the reverse reaction of Mn to Mn3O4. The successive cycles have nearly the same profiles with almost equal charge/discharge capacities with an increased Coulombic efficiency of 97.8%, which infers excellent electrochemical reversibility and greater structural integrity. Interestingly, the specific capacity of Mn3O4-NGO composite is found to be greater than its actual (theoretical) capacity, a common phenomenon observed in many previous reports of metal oxide materials as the anode in Li storage devices [31, 33, 36]. This extra capacity may be due to the storage of additional Li-ions in the grain boundaries of Li2O and metal nanoparticles formed during the reduction process. In recent times, investigations were carried out to unravel the origin of extra capacity and proposed that the generation of LiOH and subsequent reactions with Li to form Li2O and LiH is responsible for the additional charge storage capacity of metal oxide–based anode materials [31, 36].Fig. 7
Galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of a rGO, b Mn3O4, c Mn3O4-NGO, and d a comparison of charge/discharge studies of three samples (2nd cycle).

Figure 7 a and b represent the charge/discharge profiles of rGO (first five cycles) and pristine Mn3O4 (first six cycles). The first charge/discharge capacities are 127/298 mA h g−1 and 886/524 mA h g−1 with a Coulombic efficiency of 42.6 and 59.1% respectively. In contrast, the subsequent cycles of rGO and pristine Mn3O4 are not completely overlapped, indicating lower reversibility and poor stability of samples compared to Mn3O4-NGO (89.1%) composite. However, the Coulombic efficiency of rGO increases from 42.6 to 91%, and for pristine Mn3O4, it increased from 59 to 95%. A comparative charge/discharge plot (2nd cycle) of rGO, Mn3O4, and Mn3O4-NGO is presented in Fig. 7d. The specific charge capacities of the samples are 135.9, 771.7, and 1004.4 mA h g−1, respectively. Therefore, these samples’ charge/discharge analysis reveals the superiority of the Mn3O4-NGO composite in Li charge storage ability over the individual rGO and Mn3O4 components.

The cyclic stability of Mn3O4 and Mn3O4-NGO composite was tested for an initial 100 cycles as depicted in Fig. 8a–c. Pristine Mn3O4 shows an excellent initial specific capacity; however, the capacitance value fades away after the 9th cycle indicating poor stability. The decrement in capacity continues till 40 cycles; after that, it improves the capacitance value with an increase in the cycle number and maintains a high Coulombic efficiency (~ 96%). On the contrary, the MNGO composite showed greater specific capacity (898 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles), higher Coulombic efficiency (~ 98%) than pristine Mn3O4, and outstanding structural stability throughout the 100 cycles. The capacity fluctuations in the initial cycles can be seen in both materials ascribed to the anode activation process that involves the surface modifications (SEI layer construction, lithia formation) during the first Li-ion insertion/desertion process [45]. The stability of the MNGO composite was also tested at a high current density of 500 mA g−1 for 100 cycles. Even at higher current densities, it shows a decent capacity of 532 mA h g−1 (still higher than graphite anode, 372 mA h g−1) with an admirable Coulombic efficiency of 98.2%. The higher specific capacity, greater reversibility, and excellent stability of the composite arise from the synergistic amalgamation of N-doped graphene oxide and Mn3O4. These merits of the composite material can be ascribed to the N-doped graphene because the nitrogen atom introduces many topological defects on the graphene layers that effectively improve the lithium storage capacities. The Li-storage ability of the material increases with an increase in N-doping on the graphene layers due to rise in defect sites that can offer more active sites for Li-ion storage [40]. The Mn3O4 nanostructures in the composite made electrochemically more active and structurally stable hybridizing with N-doped GO. Hence, the Li-ions could be smoothly and expeditiously conducted forth and back from the Mn3O4 octahedrons into the current collector via a highly conducting N-doped carbon framework. The doped nitrogen further improves the energy storage ability and also imparts excellent stability to the metal oxide nanoparticles as suggested in the earlier research works [3, 14, 42, 47]. Furthermore, the anchoring of Mn3O4 nanoparticles on the N-doped graphene oxide shortens the Li-ion diffusion path length and the intimate interaction in the graphene sheet’s defective nitrogen sites. This results in superb electrochemical properties and stable structural integrity toward more significant volume variations in metal oxide particles during conversion reactions. These properties help to deliver high reversible capacity and faster charge transport kinetics and incur good cyclic stability [31].Fig. 8
a Cyclic stability (100 cycles) of Mn3O4 at 100 mA g−1. b Cyclic stability (100 cycles) of Mn3O4-NGO at 100 mA g−1. c Cyclic stability (100 cycles) of Mn3O4-NGO at 500 mA g−1. d Nyquist plots of rGO, Mn3O4, and Mn3O4-NGO

Based on the above results, our MNGO composite showed better charge/discharge ability, great reversible specific capacity, and outstanding structural stability compared to other materials/composites reported in the previous literature and presented in the summary Table 1.Table 1

This work

EIS measurements are used to probe the materials’ charge transfer properties and to distinguish between resistive and capacitive components of metal-oxide interfaces in energy storage applications. The Nyquist plots of rGO, Mn3O4, and MNGO composite are depicted in Fig. 8d and show typical resistance behavior at different frequency regimes. The highest frequency intersecting point on the real axis represents an equivalent series resistance (ESR) that originates from the total internal resistance. ESR is an important component that determines the total internal resistance and affects the energy efficiency of the system. The diameter of the semicircle in the high-frequency regime infers the resistance offered at the solid-electrolyte interface (SEI layer) to the diffusion of Li+ ions [45]. The composite MNGO shows the distinct smaller diameter of a semicircle that represents lower internal resistance and hence high electrical conductivity compared to rGO and Mn3O4 [3]. This lower internal resistance of MNGO is attributed to the synergistic amalgamation of metal oxide (Mn3O4) and flexible N-doped GO. The charge transfer resistance of the materials in the high-medium regime is 171.8 Ω, 146.6 Ω, and 34.8 Ω for rGO, Mn3O4, and MNGO, respectively. The low charge transfer resistance of MNGO supports the excellent electrical conductivity and faster electron transport kinetics opened by the composite with the support of N-doped GO [42, 44]. The slanting line at the low-frequency regime corresponds to the diffusion of Li+ ions between the electrode and electrolyte solution known as Warburg diffusion. Furthermore, the steeper the slope of the slant line, the faster the diffusion rate of Li-ions in the material. The MNGO is a much steeper slanting line than rGO and Mn3O4, thus clearly revealing that the composite has a more favorable interface for Li-ion diffusion [45]. The lower charge transfer resistance and steeper Warburg diffusion demonstrate a high Li-ion diffusion in the composite material that can be attributed to the harmonious interaction between Mn3O4 nanoparticles and the N-doped carbon framework. This interaction greatly enhances composite material’s electrochemical conductivity, thus providing faster and easier electrode kinetics at the interface and bulk of composite for Li+ ions during insertion/desertion [33].

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A single-step microwave-digested hydrothermal approach was employed to synthesize metal oxide embedded in N-doped graphene oxide. The structural and morphological aspects of synthesized composites were analyzed by XRD, IR, Raman, SEM, and TEM analysis. Using cyclic voltammetry and galvanostatic charge-discharge studies, the Li-ion storage capacity of the Mn3O4-NGO composite was evaluated and compared with rGO and Mn3O4. The Mn3O4 nanostructures are uniformly dispersed over the entire surface of N-doped GO. It exhibits rapid ion conductivity, excellent reversibility, and outstanding structural integrity throughout its electrochemical studies. The composite material exhibited excellent Li-ion storage properties, including a high reversible specific capacity of 898 mA h g−1 (after 100 cycles) at 100 mA g−1 with a Coulombic efficiency of 97.8%. Even after the high current density increases to a higher level of 500 mA g−1, it exhibited a reasonably good specific capacity of 532 mA h g−1 with a Coulombic efficiency of 98% after 100 cycles, which is 1.5 times higher than commercial graphite anode material. These results demonstrate that the Mn3O4 nanooctahedrons embedded on N-doped GO are a highly durable anode material for LIBs.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Pernapati Nagaraja, H. Seshagiri Rao, and P. Justin acknowledge Rajiv Gandhi University of Knowledge Technologies (RGUKT) for providing the lab facilities for the preparation of electrode materials. We thank the Department of chemistry, IIT Madras, for the lab facilities, the Material Science Research Centre (MSRC) for recording Raman, and the Department of MME, IIT Madras, for the FE-SEM facility. We thank the Advanced Materials Research Centre (AMRC), IIT Mandi, for the XPS and TEM analysis of our samples.

sec.title: Competing interests
sec.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
